column1: Will Paulo Guedes cease to be Brazil's Minister of the Economy before 1 December 2020?
column6: ['Leader Entry/Exit']
time is running out

Neither plagues nor scandals will topple Brazil’s populist president - The Economist https://www.economist.com/the-world-ahead/2020/11/17/neither-plagues-nor-scandals-will-topple-brazils-populist-president Tue, 17 Nov 2020 00:00:00 GMT

Flip-flop situation. Bolsonaro popularity falling in Sao Paulo, the nation's finanial powerhouse. But dismissing former "superminister" Guedes by 1 Dec will please neither the military faction of the government, who are now at loggerheads with "the captain" due to his showing disrespect for certain active and reserve general officers, nor the so-called Olavista faction of "Bolsonarismo" who say they like "free market" solutions.
Brazil economy staging solid 'V-shaped' recovery, job growth strong - Guedes - Reuters https://www.reuters.com/article/brazil-economy-guedes-idUSS0N2GS004 Thu, 29 Oct 2020 14:44:19 GMT

The latest big idea of the superminister Guedes, to privatize the national health service known by acronym SUS, was made into a decree by The Captain, presidente Bolsonaro. The presidential decree was published in the National Journal and became instant law. But since the state of the brand of the current regime does not inspire or attract foreign capital, the government revoked the presidential decree less than 16 hours later, not done by the Captain himself, but in a special edition of the National Journal, as if his communications team thought that that would shield the president (who is not a member of a political party) from any political blowback. Inflation is now around 3 percent (some say 2.2 percent) with food prices (including shortages of rice and soy) shooting up. This all sugests that Guedes may exit state right, particularly if Biden wins the US presidency. Here is a link from UOL in Brazilian portuguese https://economia.uol.com.br/colunas/carla-araujo/2020/10/28/sus-pressao-bolsonaro-revoga-decreto-derrota-guedes-ppi.htm
-1% per week. Also, some positive headlines:
Going to a soft round number on this one.
-1%/week

Guedes takes extra salary of R $ 21 thousand from Marinho with Bolsonaro endorsement Since March, the government has not published on the Transparency Portal the super salaries of ministers such as Marinho, Onyx and Tarcísio Freitas
as we are nearing the deadline I am decreasing the probability. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-economy-guedes-idUSKCN25D2PD

Now that Bolsonaro's #2 man in the Senate was caught by the cops hiding thousands of riais in his undies that he ripped off on a Covid-19 scam, and is apprently going to resign as part of The Captain's "team" it will make the leader and his family look bad to make his "super minister" walk the plank before Christmas time, altough there are plenty of reasons for him to be given the hook.
-1%/week
Dropping as I don't hear anything.
Decreasing due to passage of time and no new news.
-1%/week
Bolsonaro seems to be buying what Guedes is selling for now [1]
https://twitter.com/mineconomia/status/1310666525515354113?s=21
No news is good news.
Go down 1% every week.
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-09-04/brazil-house-speaker-says-ties-with-economy-minister-are-cut If austerity is totally scrapped then Guedes will quit. Watch for signs of that.
Moving closer to the average of the crowd to hedge a little
Quiet.

Economy Minister Paulo Guedes was talking about 'alternative taxes' when he was interrupted by Minister Luiz Eduardo Ramos and government leader in the Chamber, Ricardo Barros, and led away from journalists. That is General Ramos.
Actually I think staying at 5% implies too large a probability that Guedes' tax agenda will be the catalyst for his leaving, so I will lower a bit here.

Would normally decrease with passage of time, but Guedes is looking to speed up tax reform (https://news.bloombergtax.com/daily-tax-report-international/brazils-guedes-seeks-support-for-tax-on-transactions), which could cause some friction with Bolsonaro. As such, I'll stay at 5% for now.
Adjusting as time elapse.
Walking it back a bit.
https://twitter.com/guilhermeboulos/status/1305871260073832449?s=21

Since 1985, the average term of minister of the economy in Brazil is about one year (source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ministry_of_the_Economy_(Brazil)) It seems to me that changing minister of the economy is a pretty frequent issue in Brazil and not as big of a deal as it is compared to more stable, developed countries. Paulo Guedes has been in office since last January, so it not impossible that he will leave/get replaced based on this base rate. Assuming that he will follow his precedent ministers' destiny and leave the office in one year, the probability that he leaves/gets replaced in the next two months is around 15%.
Even if I am 2* times more pessimistic than the crowd I feel uncomfortable, the situation is really unstable in Brasil and increase my forecast to 15
Quite likely. Guedes has recently lost two senior officials, & his plans for an enhanced social welfare programme (Rendo Brasil) have been rejected by Pres Bolsonaro

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-cenbank-idUSKBN25L01R He called public servants parasites and was fined for it. Keeping it high awhile longer. He might hang-on but presently appears sidelined.
Using crowd forecast pushed up by a percent. Article below points at some conflict, although doesn't seem like Guedes ceasing his position is likely.

Learning Portuguese is helpful in connection with this forecasting problem. Here's another reason why... link https://noticias.uol.com.br/colunas/reinaldo-azevedo/2020/09/17/tchau-guedes-seu-chefe-tem-seus-proprios-sonhos-de-ruina-ou-teto-desaba.htm
Revision based on reports that new rifts are forming between Bolsonaro and Guedes, manifesting in the sudden ceasing of one of Guedes' projects.

Increasing based on potential disagreements between bolsonaro and guedes. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-politics/brazils-bolsonaro-scraps-new-welfare-plan-economy-minister-plays-down-rift-idUSKBN2662M6

Blosonaro has publicly revoked some of Guedes' power, killing the project that Guedes had been working on and one of his main reasons for staying(https://uk.reuters.com/article/brazil-economy-guedes/analysis-brazils-guedes-finds-influence-waning-as-bolsonaro-takes-up-spending-reins-idUKL8N2G7042). As such, i have to revise my forecast upwards a bit.

Following recent noise about the relationship between Mr Guedes and Mr Bolsonaro (thanks @kramlal and @ConnorTB for the articles) -> Bolsonaro rejected and critized Economy Minister Paulo Guedes’ strategy (more preciselt Rodrigues) to finance the program by redirecting money away from other social initiatives I update slightly my base rate. Following the same logic than for my first forecat (decomposition of the problem between he resigned before Dec 1st and he is fired by Bolosonaro) I am going to increase probabilities of the 2 buckets respectively to 7% and 4%. I still think that - The two major figures who left the cabinet were people who were closely linked to Bolsonaro's decisions related to their field. The disagreement between Bolosonaro and Guedes on economy is more subtle. - If Mr Bolsonaro fires Mr Guedes, it will impact massively the stock market as international investors trust Mr Guedes - Mr Guedes is an educated economic liberal with no future political ambition. He does not need to disaffiliate himself from Bolsonaro's balance sheet in order to protect his future.

Bolsonaro just killed the major project that Guedes had been working on and, in so doing, publicly criticized the way that Guedes handled the project. As this was one of my reasons for Guedes remaining, I am revising my forecast upward.

Hattip @Rickburger for analysis and reference as I don't read Portuguese I depend on other's analysis. There are 2-1/2 months left, I'll raise the probabilty a bit, but this seems like one more confrontation, may not be the end of the line.
Increasing my very low probabilities a little bit, because I realize I'm not really that well calibrated for low percentages. But I'm staying steady on this question.

Bolsonaro has just vetoed a pet Guedes project called Ïncome Brazil ("Renda Brasil") that was supposed neoliberal substitute to replace the Bolsa Familia (economic bootstrap for the poor and marginalizd that was a bread and butter vote getter for the Worekers Party (PT) throughout poor Northeastern Brasil and the border provinces that butt up against Peru, Colombia, Venezuela, French territoire of Guyane, Suriname etc. Renda Brazil woud reduce benefits to the poor and disabled by half, and finance the most recent el cheapo effort of the Friedmantes to play "lets go slumming" with budget cuts at other ministries that are held by political lackeys- not a smooth move because Bolsonaro is a leader without a party (unless you consider his parties to be Facebook and Twitter platforms) and he brought them on for their support and the moolah and they don't take kindly to getting their points shaved. This fiasco connected with Guedes' Superministry is viewed one more time by the captain's praetorian guard as not respecting the chain of command. Since Bolsonaro glommed onto the Bolsa Familia and the easy money it provides to the marginalized, and the welfare fraudsters imbedded among them, his populacrity in those regions has increased and the PT and their "leftist" cohorts are on the slippery slope. The deputy minster who helped Guedes develop Renda Brasil, is now in the "fritura" process, and his days are numbered. The question now becomes when the captain finally gives Guedes the hook. Link in Brazilian Portuguese https://www1.folha.uol.com.br/mercado/2020/09/bolsonaro-veta-desindexacao-e-sinaliza-novo-golpe-a-agenda-de-guedes.shtml

Upping prediction given the recent reports of Bolsonaro not being able to find an agreement with Guedes over deficit in order to fund Renda Brasil. This is yet another signal of controversy mounting, and I believe I was underestimating Guedes's probability of resigning before today.
Mantaining forecast for the week. Interesting to see that the aggregate has gone 10->5% in a couple of days.

Bringing back prediction to 9% after recent bill was rejected by Bolsonaro and Guedes needed to defend that this was not targeting him, but the bill itself. https://blinks.bloomberg.com/news/stories/QGPHMT073NCW
Decay of forecast with time and lack of material news
Updated based on passage of time

As @cls stated, Guedes's proposal was accepted by Bolsonaro on a recent bill, which may indicate that there is not much conflict there. Also passage of time with no new rumors on Guedes's resignation (or forced replacement) lead me to adjust downwards.
adjust based on team rationale
Dropping as time continues / skewing based on crowd prediction.
Adjusting downwards after budget was passed successfully and on the back of @cls comment
Go down 1% every 2 weeks.
Assume inertia continues doing what it does best.
Share much of the same logic as my teammates. I also buy the argument by @cls that the lack of major news recently lowers the probability that Guedes will be replaced.
Likelihood reducing as we get closer to settlement, and with now dramatically different updates coming out of Brazil than before.

I slowly decrease my probability now because no major news. On google news there are few articles but mainly in Portuguese and more in favor of Guedes staying For instance in [1], President Jair Bolsonaro complied with the recommendation of Minister Paulo Guedes and vetoed a provision that granted amnesty in taxes to be paid by churches in the country, a measure that could have an impact of R $ 1 billion.
My Probability dist had a peak around release of budget but with more time passing since it's release I'm reducing accordingly

We have a starting point base rate of 25% derived from historical changes within ministries. We then apply a bayesian approach here and question the current state of brazil's economy. With covid having been in effect for several months in Brazil and with Guedes still in office I think that lowers the chance he will cease to be minister by December 1. With 3 months left in effect I think the "chatter" would be worse by now but given that the worst has already occurred this lowers my prediction. Diminishing returns to figures leaving the office also supports my reasoning.

Lowering probability due to recently proposed bill that is in line with Guedes fiscal policy goals, while increasing the President's power over the public sector. https://in.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-economy-reform-idINKBN2602AD
Bolsonaro needs to keep him around as a scapegoat for when nothing gets better. Could be close to 6 December, but I think after the first of the year instead.
Just fiddling with the numbers.
Bolsonaro has removed Guedes from negotiating with their Congress on the economy and is moving at light speed away from Guedes austerity as Bolsonaro’s popularity declines. Will Guedes quit?
Team consensus + lack of recent speculation is good news for Guedes. only needs to survive 3 months!

Speculation surrounding a Guedes departure has died down quite a bit recently, and was perhaps a bit inflated due to health minister turnover in earlier stages of the Covid crisis. Moreover, given that he and Bolsonaro have made headway on certain policy disagreements, there doesn't seem to be much reason to expect his departure, and I don't want to be anchored to a higher-than-reasonable probability just because the question is being asked -- I agree with others who have said that it would take a fairly new, unexpected development for Guedes to leave at this point.

I think I'm ready to revise down my estimate. Based on recent news (translated with google lol), there have been no mentions of a possible Bolsonaro resignation in the past week or so, compared with several articles per week (in both American and Brazilian publications) at the height of the speculation. This would prompt me to lower my probability to (what I estimate to be) the base rate before the speculation began. I am further lowering the probability of resignation because Bolsonaro's popularity has continued to soar, making it very unlikely that he will shake things up and disrupt the market/economy by firing Guedes.
Resignation seems highly unlikely given Guedes has already confirmed he has no plans to do so. Agree with @dzhou3 and @vkasat logic to calculate the chance of Guedes getting dismissed.

There are 22 cabinet members, 2 of whom have left. Albeit recently, it is very important to note that Guedes himself has stated he has no intention of resigning. Thus, only a large enough disagreement between Guedes and Bolsanaro can lead to Guedes being fired before December 1st.

There needs to be another catalyst in Brazilian politics for this to happen in my estimation. I do not think the current budget disagreements are enough to force a resignation. Given volatility in Brazilian politics over the past few years however, it would be naive to rule the scenario out completely.

There is a lot of public documentation of th erelationship between Guedes and Bolsonaro, but as @repstein rightly points out, there is little reason to assume that this 3 month stretch is going to be so dramatically different from the last three month stretch, such that Guedes would choose to quit. The argument can be made that given that he hasn't quit by now, if nothing material has changed about his position, it should be less likely that he quits in the next three months. Obviously, this forecast will have to be monitored/updated based on new information released.
Initial forecast based on team & crowd consensus - slightly extremized

At the time of this question's creation, Brazil was facing major struggles and criticisms on it's handling of the coronavirus situation. This resulted in the firing of Brazil's Health Minister. Shortly thereafter, the successor to the Health Minister position resigned four week later. Other members that have left Bolsonaro's cabinet include the Chief Justice Minister who resigned as a protest to Bolsonaro's firing the federal police chief. As @hermannviktor pointed out, these departures were due to catalysts in Brazillian politics, such as the coronavirus pandemic, and it is unclear what/when the next catalyst might be.

Baseline: So far 2 Health ministers, the Justice Minister and the Education Minister lost their position this year. Out of these 4 occurrences, 3 happened upon Bolsonaro's decision and 1 happened due to a scandal. Brazil has 16 cabinet members, thus so far around 1/4 of the cabinet has lost their position. However, we need to account for the fact that most of those happened amid turmoils in politics mainly due to Covid. Therefore, we need to try to predict how likely it is that there will be another catalyst in Brazilian politics that will make Guedes leave his position.

Looking at latest news regarding the stories the following links seem to have importance: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-economy-guedes/brazil-economy-minister-paulo-guedes-not-about-to-resign-sources-idUSKCN25D2PD https://www.ft.com/content/c63d45a1-8e79-42df-84a8-00f7b089ca88 https://www.economist.com/the-americas/2020/09/05/brazils-president-and-his-economy-minister-start-to-disagree

Base rate: I first looked at the rate of economy ministers that resigned but it was really high as they all finally resigned. So here for me the question is more on the date: December 1st. I do think the probability that Paulo Guedes resigns is high, estimated at 0.8. Now, the question is to estimate the probability that he will resign / be fired before Dec 1st. - he resigned before Dec 1st Comparison with the 2 other cases: : Moro was the star of the Brazilian government because of the Car Wash investigation. He enjoys the support of the majority of Brazilians, more than Bolsonaro, whose popularity is in decline. Contrarily to Moro, Mr Guedes is an educated economic liberal with no future political ambition. He does not need to disaffiliate himself from Bolsonaro's balance sheet in order to protect his future. Regarding the health ministry, again the comparison does not make that much sense as Brazil was one of the countries was one of the countries worst affected by covid-19. It has had 4m confirmed cases largely on the president’s fault. Given this disastrous health results, it is unsurprising to see such unstability at health ministy. On the other hand, Salim Mattar, Brazil’s privatization secretary, and Paulo Uebel, the debureaucratisation secretary, walked out on August 11 after complaining about the lack of progress in the government’s economic agenda. At the time of the news Mr Guedes understood the sign of dissatisfaction as the trademark reforms had stumbled during the coronavirus crisis, but placing the blame on the “political establishment”. but it was already almost a month ago ans he is still here -> proba 15% [1] - he is fired by Bolsonaro: low probable 2% as it will impact massively the stock market as international investors trust Mr Guedes, no real rationale for this [1] https://www.ft.com/content/c63d45a1-8e79-42df-84a8-00f7b089ca88

Let us break down the question into the following components: Will Guedes cease to be Brazil's Minister of the Economy and if so, will it happen before 1 December 2020. Yes, Guedes could simply resign and that appears the most likely reason he would leave given his division with the PM but there could be other factors for his departure as well (e.g. Bolsanaro just replaces him). Since Minister of the Economy Pedro Malan (I use him as a starting point since Minister of Economies before him served very short terms and would seem not to generate a reasonable base rate), only 1/6 Ministers of the Economy have resigned. Thus, we put the probability that Guedes leaves his position at slightly higher to adjust for other reasons for his "departure" -> 22%. Now determining his departure before 1 December 2020 is harder. At best I put this at 33% based on the news sentiment. Thus the probability that he leaves his position before 1 December 2020 becomes 7.26%.

Base rate for resigning, even under Bolsonaro's administration, is not particularly high. Bolsonaro and Guedes have had public clashes but nothing out of the ordinary for this administration. I think it is less likely that he will resign given that he has no future political ambitions, and this is a relatively short timeline for resigning. The other two cabinet members that resigned likely had catalysts due to COVID and other geopolitical events, but there does not seem to be another similar catalyst on the horizon.

As of now, doesn't seem likely that Guedes will step down. Although it seems like he has settled disagreement with Bolsonaro, it is worth noting that Guedes and Rodrigo Maia, the speaker of Brazil's lower house, have "cut ties". Thus, I believe there is a non-trivial chance of a resignation within the next few months.

Reasons he might resign: - There was significant speculation that he might resign after the previous resignations of two ministers in the administration. At most, it seemed like maybe a 1/3 chance of him resigning at the time. As mentioned in the articles, there is ongoing tension about the administration's economic policies. The president has extended significant social benefit programs in response to the coronavirus, but Guedes is a staunch UChicago school economist. He opposes any renewal of Brazil's previous proclivity for excessive spending. - He recently lost another battle to Bolsonaro on a matter relatively unrelated to the government's coronavirus response. At Guedes' request, the government freezed hiring for new positions (previously existing positions could still be filled). This was just lifted so Brazil's FBI and FDA could hire more investigators, among other new employees. This seems like the administration is kind of spitting in the fact of Guedes', as this policy change delivers him another defeat on a relatively unimportant issue. - Guedes' is the subject of an investigation into his dealings with pension funds. However, the investigation was opened in 2018 and there have been few, if any, developments since then. Also, Brazil's justice system moves relatively slowly. He would only be forced to leave if massive revelations came to light and the public demanded his ouster. Bolsonaro is also no friend of the justice system, and he is more likely than not to oppose any attempts by the justice department to intervene in his administration. - previous ministers of the economy have stayed in office for about 1 year on average. Guedes' is on the longer end of the typical range. That being said, it seems like ministers who are the first to fill their position in that administration stay longer than replacements.
Updating with the crowd forecasters

Guedes is more isolated than ever before. Does he have the will to fight indefinitely and be reliant on variables. Didn't quite do justice for the resignations earlier this month.
Cutting in half, no news is good news.

Some Brazilian news sources say Bolsanaro’s patience with Guedes plans to increase economy has run out. Here is why: “The issue is economic. Too much unemployment and a population undergoing perrengue will make him arrive in 2022 well dehydrated. Bolsonaro's issue is the spending limit. I don't know if Paulo Guedes will stay until the end of the year”. Bolsanaro does not want the fiscal restraints and the 2021 budget is to be sent to their Congress soon.
Backing way down, to just a heart beat level, no news is no news.
The press likes to talk bullshit, and doesn't like Guedes or Bolsonaro. But Guedes didn't get fired the last time the press reported about it. Or the time before that. Or the time before that.
Hattip @Rickburger and @fisherdbus for their insights and references that help illuminate a situation only visible in Brazil.

Shaky right now. Article in Portuguese: São Paulo - Minister Paulo Guedes seems to have his days numbered under Jair Bolsonaro's government. On Tuesday (25), at the launch of the Casa Verde e Amarela program, considered “fake” by former Planning Minister Miriam Belchior, the head of the Economy did not even appear. The next day, he was tugged on by the president, who refused to discuss the economic team's text on “Renda Brasil”, with which the Executive intends to replace Bolsa Família.
https://en.mercopress.com/2020/08/26/brazilian-central-bank-chief-and-economy-minister-are-fully-aligned https://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-economy-guedes-idUSKCN25D2PD

Raising forecast a point based on headline on mainstream UOL online site reporting today that Guedes missing a key meeting may sugest the starting of the process of "frying him" known as "fritura" in Brazilian Portugese, or "firing" or his "submitting his resignation" (he has threatened before) and voices among the military praetorian guard who are close to the president saying "no minister is irreplacable" are ominous signs. Link https://economia.uol.com.br/colunas/carla-araujo/2020/08/25/guedes-falta-a-evento-no-planalto-explicita-insatisfacao-e-expoe-fritura.htm

Big change here. Why? Much will depend on whether Trump wins a second term in the US electoral college. MSM in Brazil often characterizes Guedes as having a good relationship the active duty and "retired" military senior officers who are Bolsonaro's praetorian guard. The extended social benefits paid by federal government during Guedes' watch, to poor individuals and families who are hard hit by COVID-19 pandemia aren't much. But they are helping stabilize- and in some cases- increase the Captain's popularity in the impoverished Northeastern states which pretty much went against him full tilt in the 2016 elections. The political consequences of these benefits, (these benefits are quite small considering the the amounts of money the political class misappropriate) however, will lead to consequeces down the road, after December because of the way the federal government pays, and collects and "defers" taxes for plutocratic interests. Guedes has been quoted in Brazil media as being always ready to resign if he feels it is necessary, may have to wait until economic data after all the ignominous "black fridays" and a possible pickup of the economy after Christmas sales are measured, which is after the closing date of this problem.
Cutting half again. Why?
Lowering my initial forecast, it appears Paulo Guedes will remain Brazil’s minister of Economy for the foreseeable future.

Up a tick. Latest education minister, was named last week in the official journal but already has resigned over what can be described as a fake, tricked out resume, even before he was to be officially sworn in by the prez. Vetting, even Brazilian-style, didn''t seem to be much of a priority. Link https://www.dailysabah.com/world/americas/future-ex-minister-brazils-education-minister-resigns-over-fraudulent-diplomas

This is a tough one. As FarShooter is Brazilian and has inside knowledge I will use his information. Sebawi also makes a good point that the military runs things and as long as Guedes does not totally run afoul of the military’s agenda then he will stay.
I'll step this up as a head fake and maybe drop back again.

More pressure. From a Brazilian Article: “As economic activity collapses amid the pandemic of the covid-19, and lawsuits in the Judiciary are advancing on the surroundings of the Plateau, President Jair Bolsonaro increased the charges to the Minister of Economy, Paulo Guedes. In search of a lifeline for good news, the president wants more tangible results in the economic area. Unable to deliver what he promised since the pension reform was approved, Guedes is running out of arguments to maintain the optimistic speech of a robust resumption of the economy after the crisis. The forecast for the fall of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) for this year is constantly being revised downwards. “Certainly, Guedes will be charged for results and to provide more incentives, especially for spending on infrastructure. The Centrão will demand more presence in the government in exchange for supporting Bolsonaro's political survival. I cannot see in the same equation Guedes, Centrão and Planalto military. Someone is left over and, in this case, it is the Minister of Economy ”, evaluated Sergio Vale, chief economist at MB Associados.“ Going to up chances he will be out.

Going up to 30% while I consider whether Bolsonaro is likely to be impeached or otherwise affected by the courts. Most importantly, if it's clear that Bolsonaro wouldn't win the next elections, or if Guedes thinks that Bolsonaro's regime is beyond reputational redemption, leaving might become a more attractive option.
Changing my view completely, because it seems Brazil has an unexpectedly independent and rigid judiciary (their luck and final salvation, maybe).

With the Treasury Secretary resigning on June 15 and the government of Jair Bolsonaro seeming to fall apart at the seams, it seems fitting that Paulo Guedes would consider leaving a sinking ship as well.
Brazil is on the brink of civil unrest, and Bolsonaro's government will fail.

Guedes is certainly toeing the line for Bolsonaro, but seems to be making claims that are completely impossible to be valid [1], as the number of daily cases are at a record high [2]. They are also pushing drugs that are not well supported by the science [3].

Guedes is pushing for austerity reforms and is cited by Bloomberg [1] to be "growing tired of losing budget battles in Congress and has given signs that his future in the administration depends on Bolsonaro’s support for his austerity agenda." Economy Minister Paulo Guedes told aides last week that he will step down if the government removes any secretariat from the portfolio to transform it into a new ministry. Members of the economic team, however, said that Guedes does not believe that President Jair Bolsonaro (without a party) will make that decision. The minister has been working behind the scenes to block attempts to negotiate his ministry's secretaries with Centrão's parties. Members of the Republicans say the government has offered the party to head the Special Secretariat for Productivity, Employment and Competitiveness, now headed by Carlos da Costa. * The information is from Crusoé magazine

As part of the "fritura" (the frying or pre-firing process in Brazilian Portuguese political slang) process, the current president is distancing himself from the fact that the second phase of Brasil's COVID-19 stimulus package to needy citizens is being held up and as of now, no date as to when these funds will be made available has been set. "ask Guedes" is the generic reply from the presidency, that one finds in online media and on social media. One could view that as "throwing someone under the bus." An image of Guedes wearing a mask at a photo-op where the president and some others serving in his cabinet were not wearing mask went viral. This could be interpreted by some among the presidency as Guedes, wittingly showing disrespect for the "chain of command." Then too, the president and those close to him wear masks on occasion to palliate critics. It all might turn on what happens during the US presidential election campaign, who wins, and whether Brazil will need to start printing money and fund up social programs, which are an anethema to the "Chicago school" (and closet Hayekistas) that Guedes was chosen by the president's "transition team" to represent. Not even the "mas Mies menos Marx" guerrilla grafitti campaign one sees stenciled on the sides of buildings in some major urban areas are going to help. When, not if.
Bolsonaro is alienating everyone around him, even old allies and given the economic damage due to Covid-19 he'll need someone to throw under the bus.
I have no data, just seems like a good idea at the time. The wind appears to be blowing in the right direction.

Because I made a keyboard error on my previous forecast. I think there is at this time a 73 percent chance Guedes will not be Brazil's Minister of the Economy on 1 Dec 2020.

Guedes was appointed in 1/1/19, at the beginning of the Bolsonaro term. It appears that over the last 30 years, slightly less than two-thirds of individuals in this post were replaced within 23 months of appointment (which would be his tenure at the end of the time-period in question). I can see reasons to increase or decrease due to certain "inside view" factors, but they generally cancel each other out. Sticking with the base rate.
Politics being anti-inductive and the press privileging hypothesis, I'm going with a 40%, though it feels more like a 30%. That being said, I expect to update this.

De facto, the military rules Brazil. Guedes is not calling the shots on most of the economic issues anymore [1]. It may be too risky for Bolsonaro to officially sack him at the moment, so if Guedes does not resign by himself, I don't think Bolsonaro will fire him. That said, up until now he remains an influential minister, at least due to the financial market [2,3]. He may hold on for a few months to see if he can make a comeback as his economic approach may be in demand again if the economic crisis prevails.
